90 THOMAS STAPLETON’S USE or MORE’s ENGLISH WORKs

More’s English Works also yielded information for Stapleton's life of Thomas Becket. He learned from More, he says, that Becket bore the first brunt of Protestant iconoclasm: the destruction of the statue of Becket on London Bridge was an omen of the wholesale assault which was to take place in 1538 by royal edict.⁷

Thus Stapleton’s glosses, underlinings, and vertical lines in More's English Works show how carefully and thoroughly he read that folio volume in preparation for his Vita Mori. A comparison of his Latin with the passages he translated from More's English would also reveal his skill and accuracy as a translator.
